												This game is very hit and miss. It usually does things amazingly well, or very poorly, sometimes both at the same time. The best thing about this game is the art design. The world is very attractive, and you can tell that a lot of time and work has gone into making the world and puzzles. The manual you get is also very detailed and impressive.The worst thing about the game is the character movement. A lot of the time you don't know where you can and can't go, and even worse, when you click the wrong spot, it won't let you pick a new spot until you've arrived at the wrong spot. This along with the character's slow movement speed is a mild form of torture.The puzzles were very creative and some were quite rewarding. The downside is that some were simple and tedious, meaning that you would know exactly what to do, but it took a while to complete all the actions required to solve the puzzle. Others had somewhat arbitrary solutions. The gear puzzles were awful for this, because you could connect gears to turn the gear at the end, but it would have to be done in an exact way. There was no flexibility for multiple solutions. Worse yet, there were times where you had to add gears that did nothing at all. That's just pointless and it ruins the puzzle for people who have a brain and aren't solving it with a solution guide. The story and music were underwhelming. The plot without spoilers is that you play as a child fixing problems for adults who are too incompetent or lazy to fix them for themselves. I wanted to enjoy the game more, but it was just too tedious for the most part, and the fulfilling puzzles were too scarce.

Short version: 81%Lumino City is a game that instantly grabs the attention with its unique, imaginative art style. The price tag is undoubtedly steep, but it is attached to a rather long game with a plethora of surprisingly difficult puzzles.Long version:In 2011, a game called Lume awed its audience with its fun and creative art design, filmed entirely at a hand-made paper and cardboard house. It took years for to finally get a sequel, but a single glance tells why: the game takes place in an entire city now, crafted with even more detail. Just building this set probably took years, and it’s a marvel of architectural design and crafting.Great art style alone wouldn’t make a game though, as Lume painfully proved it. So we finally get a full-fledged puzzle adventure with a huge number of unique brain twisters. They share one fallacy of Lume, sadly: none of them are ever explained, so sometimes it is a task to figure out the basic mechanics before any attempt can be made at the solutions themselves.This problem is present in the levels too. There are no hot spots, so most of the game time is spent clicking frantically to finally find that one interactive pixel that holds the key of progress. Sure, this turns Lumino City into an old-school puzzle game that doesn’t hold the player’s hand, but it also makes game mechanics feel dated and frustrating, preventing us from fully immersing ourselves in the magical atmosphere of the scenery.

												This game is pure genius.Well, maybe not so literally, but it's up there. It's a point and click adventure/puzzle game where you play the role of Lumi who is off to find out where her Granddad ended up. Your trek begins at the entrance to *drumroll...* Lumino City and immediately starts of with a rather tame puzzle (graph theory majors need not apply).The game sports not too difficult of a challenge puzzle wise, but just enough to keep your brain sharp. It doesn't take long to figure out how to solve most of them, but even if you get stuck, your granddad was nice enough to leave you with a 1000 page handyman's guide, (which contains a whole lot of nonsense actually), but contains hints as to how to solve each puzzle, if you can decode what page number they are on. It's simple math formulas based on the puzzle you solve, but it's still pretty ingenious. "Going to the book" seems very 7th Guest style to me, so that's pretty neat.The soundtrack is amazing. It's not over the top as to be annoying, just well suited for the puzzle you're solving and the area you happen to be in. Some catchy stuff here.The visuals are awesome. Remember all those little carboard houses and things you used to make as a kid or would simply dream up and wish you had them? Well, albeit physically impossible, this game has brought a sort of quaint fantasy world that melds Pleasantville with Little Big Planet and managed to keep it from being hokey. It's almost like you're playing inside of a giant dollhouse, or something built out of tinker toys. The mixture of gadgets and propaganda you'd find in the 50's adds a nice touch.The gameplay is pretty simple: you point- you go. That's pretty much it. There's no (very little) backtracking, so if you can manage to get to a new area, chances are, you found all that you need. The game limits the backtracking you have to do by making past areas inaccessible once you move on- preventing you from moving on until you have everything. It's a little linear in that regard because it's not true to the adventure games of yore, when you could legitimately break your game by forgetting something in the beginning (which is a♥♥♥♥♥♥move we all secretly loved). The puzzles are difficult, but not so difficult you just give up and resort to cheating, which is refreshing.Give this game a try, you won't regret it.

 A highly creative and endearing puzzle game that has some minor issues. Lumino City is basically a game built upon clever and almost realistic puzzle problems. I say almost realistic because it grounds its puzzle logic in basic arithmetic and mechanical systems but still exagerating it for fantastical effect. Think of the logic in say a Rube Goldberg Machine. And that's what I love about this game. Fun yet challenging puzzle solving. Another striking thing about the game is the stop motion aesthetic and graphics. Lumino City is set in a mixture of exagerated 1950's tech but with a nice of touch of an English countryside town. While playing this, I've felt that charm and  grabbing wit of say the film, Toy Story. Good old wholesome aesthetic that really captures the imagination of why a community would be built around such strange and wonderful machinery. However the graphics ties in nicely with my biggest gripe with the game. It runs at locked 25 fps. I guess that's because they filmed the stop motion animations at something like that. And I'm fine with my AMD R9 290 chugging a pitiful 25fps if the game kept it at that. But during level transitions, cutscenes, and ordinary scenery object movement, it constantly halves it the framerate to like 12 fps. That's bad especially when you have a few puzzle dependent on precise point n' clicking. Which brings another gripe, input seems so vague. My guess is because the game was built as a mobile game instead of your average PC adventure game. I often miss clicked points of interest just because what you click is based on a general area and not the point you clicked. Think of touch screen input and the problems with that and you'll have an idea as to my problems with input in the game. Also, there is no resolution options, audio options, or any of that stuff in the game. Just defaults to your primary displays resolution. Again, a sign that they mostly built the game around mobile devices.But after all that I still love the game. The first game they made, Lume, was charming but a fleeting experience. And this one seems to have taken the charm, wit, and fun of the first one and just amplified it for a lasting effect. Sure, my completion time says this is a short game. Hey, a lot of adventure games are short so why would you expect this to be 200 hours long like a Civilization game or DOTA2. But that's beside the point. If your a fan of the genre you'd understand why adventure games have a different pace to them compared to other games.Oh, about the story of it. There's not much plot other than say the Lumino City's story. Your not going to be having exposition long cutscenes. You do talk to characters but mostly it's a one off thing. Characters are tied to the environment and scene they're in so you mostly won't see them again. But that doesn't really bother me because I realize that the story of Lumino City itself is a lot more engaging than the individuals you meet. Though they are interesting enough to reinforce that environmental story telling the game's got going for itself. So conclusion , I love it and I hope that if you've read this review I manage to inform you as to why I think it's a great game. Oh, and the soundtracks fantastic so get that soundtrack edition if you can.It seems to have not sold well. But I hope the developers, State of Play Games, manages to make another like it. If not a sequel but something as charming as this game with a little more attention to the pc version, then yeah that'll make me happy.

												Lumino City is the kind of game that when you look at it at first you think "Woah, it looks really pretty!" with how it uses real life objects and structures to its world, then going into the game and playing it, you find out that it's a really adorable puzzle game.To come clean first, I'm not a big puzzle guy, and I only legitimately finished half of the game with it's puzzles, and the rest of it I 'finished what I can' til the end, ehm.Obviously it's main attraction is its looks, and it actually does look really nice with its real life structures, and specially seeing it moving because of the characters interaction with it. The second attraction is its puzzles, with all of the them in each level starting easy and ending exceptionally hard, and how the those puzzles are connected in some way with the environment and its story. The last attraction is its exploration, its journey, and its simple small story.What I didn't like about the game is that there is no hint system in place, or it at least it wasn't made visible if there is one, for people like me that aren't so hardcore gamers in the puzzle genre. Another issue I found is, when you start an action like climbing stairs, or walking to another area, you cannot cancel that action, which isn't a big problem but I still found it a small nuisance nonetheless.Edit: Apparently there was a hint system. The hints are and spread around in a massive book you carry, explaining the puzzles you're stuck in, so that solves that issue. Guess the book was too overwhelming at first glance to notice there was hints in it.Overall Lumino City is a great puzzle adventure game with handcrafted passion that's to be admired, with puzzles to satisfy the puzzle loving gamers, but not so much for the casual crowd, and for the price it's going for, I'd personally go for 15 dollars, but I don't think the current price is bad either for what the game is.Shameless link[www.ksalue.com] to original post.

												I have finally gotten around to finishing this game!When it comes to me and point and clicks, I find it hard to play them continually until they are finished. I have nothing against the game in-particular in this aspect, I just often get stuck on a puzzle or part of the game very easily and end up taking lengthy breaks before working myself up to having another go. That happened a few times with this game and although it’s tedious for me and my feeble little brain, I actually consider it a good quality amongst puzzle games. The puzzles were interesting, challenging and at the most part, bar a few tedious ones for me (Morse code kinda♥♥♥♥♥♥, fun. I would say in terms of the point and click games I have played this has been one of the games with the best puzzles.In terms of a hint or help system, I couldn’t really figure out if there was one (Which I guess within itself says a lot). You’re given a “handy manual” but for the life of me, I couldn’t figure it out. Luckily for me, taking breaks between getting stuck was good enough for me. That said, most point and click games centralise around story. This game doesn’t. I felt that with this game the centre was most definitely the puzzles. There is still a story, and it’s not horrifyingly bad, but it is definitely not the spotlight component.The graphics and style to this game definitely come second in terms of importance to me. A lot of work was put into building this game and every time I came back to it I was no less impressed with how well it has been put together. The style is so unique and beautiful that it’s hard to not enjoy this game if only for that. The entire setting is warm, colourful and homely. All in all, it was a great game and I’m glad that this full length game was released, which helped to make up for it’s demo-lengthed predecessor “Lume”. The devs did a great job with this one, I look forward to any future games they release.TL;DR : Puzzles are interesting, challenging and fun. The story is slightly lacking, although not terrible, but that’s only because of the focus on the puzzles. The graphics, style and work put into this game is amazing and it’s a definite must-try for fans of the point and click genre.

												I never grew up playing point and click adventures game so naturally I don't carry any nostalgia for them.  I usually don't play too many of them because I personally find them quite difficult.  Many times puzzles require you make specific associations between different items or require you to find hidden details in the picturesque backgrounds.  Lumino City does a fabulous job separating itself from the crowd as an exemplary model of how a game in the genre should feel like.  A gorgeous art style, a wonderful sense of adventure, and cleverly designed puzzles make this game wonderfully endearing experienceThe first thing that will immediately grab you're attention is the art style.  The game has a vibrant paper-craft look that just pops right out of the screen.  The world looks so real you feel like you could just reach right through the screen and touch it.  The is especially notice able during the little transitioning scenes during key parts of the story where you can see the world from different angles.  The natural abstraction of the paper-craft fits perfectly with the idea of a city built on a giant waterwheel.There is a wonderful sense of adventure as you explore Lumino City.  On a journey to recuse your Granddad you'll have to traverse the city.  Each puzzle in the game offers two of three locales to explore.  The progression as you go from one area next fells very natural and offers a wonder sense of discovery.  This city has some wild architecture and you'll meet so very interesting indiviuals along the way.  You really never know what to expect and its always exciting to see whats around the next corner.Well balanced puzzles is essential for this kind of game and Lumino City nails the balance superbly.  Yes, the puzzles can get quite difficult and many of the will really make you think.  However, patience is a virtue and the game gives you all the tools you'll need to figure out the solution.  Since you're limited a certain amount of space and resources for each puzzle you'll never feel too overwhelmed.  The variety is off the charts, every puzzle is unique and will have you thinking in a totally different way using a vast array of intellectual skills.Playing this game is just incredibly rewarding.  The puzzles are all challenging yet they are all reasonable.  Every time you find the solution and progress to the next area its there is a wonderful sense of accomplishment.  Not only that but you're just dying to see whats next in this beautifully handcrafted world.  Not everybody will have the patience for these challenges but I highly recommend giving this game a shot.

												Let's get the obvious good news out of the way: this game is totally gorgeous, and the setting/writing are very charming. I look forward to the creative people on this game moving on to other projects, on teams with testers.This game crashed on me multiple times, plus one soft-lock. Luckily there's auto-saves every few screens, so I never lost much progress. (There's also an auto-save that drops you back exactly where you were, but that dropped me AFTER the soft-lock, so you might occasionally need to rewind further. Since there's no walking-dead states in any of the puzzles when they're *working correctly*, I suspect this rewind feature was actually made just so people could work around such bugs...)I actually loved many of the puzzles in this game, and they're all generally good ideas in theory... but too many of the puzzles (or even just the act of traveling from one screen to the next) were hampered by really confusing layout/perspective problems... I lost track of how many times I spent entire minutes just combing the screen with clicks, until suddenly the character stepped through what had seemed to be a wall, onto what I thought was part of the background. One puzzle has MANY instances of this, and you'll be real sick of it by the end. (It doesn't seem like intentional 'trickery', I think the developers just didn't realise how unclear the visuals are...)There were also several puzzles where I understood the nature of the puzzle, but actually finding the correct *solution* required so much trial and error (with no way to narrow it down or intuit whether you were getting close) that it just took far too long to be fun.I guess these complaints sound mostly minor, and there is a LOT of charm here in between the long stretches of trying to figure out how to implement the puzzle solutions you've thought of, but in the end the problems were frustrating enough and made it drag enough in the bad parts that the only reason I didn't give up was because I was fairly sick at the time and had nothing else to do. I've certainly played far far worse games than this, but ultimately I'd just have a hard time justifying suggesting that someone set aside the time to play this, unless they're extremely eager to play a new puzzle adventure game and have long since run out of the better ones.

												If I was to only review the hint system alone.  This game would be a recommend, but the game that includes that hint system still receives extremely high marks.   While it's not perfect, it's a fun little game, and my only complaint is the price. To start with, this is yet another point and click adventure.  However what stands out in this game is the graphics.  This game isn't just beautiful, it's stylized and gorgeous.  Everything has a feeling of depth, and the papercraft style it, and that's because it was.  Literally this game was made out of cardboard and paper, and then photographed, and holy crap, this game look unbelievable. The one negative thing I could say is the player character kind of looks weak against this unbelievably gorgeous world.  I mean this game is astonishing.   It's just that good looking. The puzzles in this game though are good, but they almost don't live up to the graphics.  The graphics are a solid 10, the puzzles are 7 or 8.  They're good mind you, but they can range from almost too easy to insanely hard due to the wrong reasons.  For instance there was a puzzle I just couldn't figure out, I couldn't figure out how to make a boat rock.  I solved two other puzzles, and I was feeling damn good about myself.  Then I finally had to look up a guide, and it turned out I was missing a hatch on the boat, I spent at least 10 minutes just trying to find a way to rock the boat, and it was something that almost blended in with the screen.  A similar issue happened at another point (I missed a tool).   But these are the exception.  There's very little pixel hunting required.  Most times you need an item it's blatantly obvious what you need (or maybe I'm just that lucky), but I was stymied twice so far. However for the puzzles themselves if you get stuck the game has something special.  There's a book that you're given at the beginning of the game, and while it looks confusing at first, the table of contents actually is intended to work.  The book has over a thousand pages of random stuff, but it also contains solutions for the puzzles in the game.  To look up a solution, there's usually a question related to the puzzle, that leads to a small math problem that tells the player which page to look up.  The only flaw with this hint system is it gives a complete solution.  There's no hint, if you go to that page, you're going to see a decent (about 5 percent) of the game's puzzles' solution exposed.  It's mostly in order, so if you can avoid scanning the whole page you might be ok, but it's still VERY spoiler.  However it allows the gamer to not have to look up solutions... as long as you have all the items to get you to that solution (for instance it doesn't mention the location of the spanner I was missing.) I just love the idea of the hint book however, and I will rave about it, because it's actually quite fun to have to look up a solution, since there's very little chance you'll run across solutions for other puzzles while you find yours. Now the one thing I wasn't a huge fan of is the sound.  The game is gorgeous, and fun to play, but there's nothing special about the sound.  There's no voice acting and almost nothing going on with the sound design.  There's nice music, but that's about it.  Just songs, and silence.   A shame, because visually this game is a feast, but the sound seems to lag behind. The one big negative though for this game is length.  And that's about the only place I think this game falls short.   It's a gorgeous feast for the eyes, but only about 4-5 hours long, less if you use the hint system relentlessly.   That's ok, but at 20 bucks, this game is WELL overpriced.  However this game does go on sale often, and it would be a "must buy" for less, but at 20 bucks, that's a value question each gamer is going to have to decide.   I got this game through a humble bundle, so that wasn't a big issue for me, but it definitely deserves a mention as it's short for 20 bucks. Overall though, I'd recommend Lumino city if you can get at a discount.  10 dollars is probably worth it, 5 dollars is an easy purchase.  This game is just unbelievably beautiful that I can't stress it enough, the only issue is eventually the game comes to an end, and I don't think I'll be returning for a second playthrough any time soon.  But for those four or five hours, it's really incredible.

												In rare moments, buying something doesn't feel like giving away money but rather being privileged to come across a great find. This game was one of those experiences to me.What I loved most about this game is the relaxed simplicity. There's no overweight drama, no feeling of urgency, no unecessary tension; just a simple, calm and welcoming vibe from start to end. Its artwork really shines through and the fact that it was made of real world materials brings more applaud to the artists - it makes the experience lively, warm and homey. The level design is also ingenious and the creativity in the puzzles is well brought together. Also the handy manual is a cool trick basically saying you'll have to work your way into finding the actual answers if you're too lazy to figure them out. The story line floats seamlessly as you progress and the characters you'll meet have their own unique personalities and show little insights into their mundane struggles that adds a nice flavour to the experience. The action happens in a surreal environment but the plot feels very real and relatable to anyone who started their life, bringing up themes like friendship, family, living in a crowded area, modern energy resources and more which you can discover by yourself.The only part I didn't enjoy was the interface. For example it takes a bit of a pavlovian response to learn that hitting the Esc key (which every gamer knows as the pause menu key) will only make the game exit fullscreen. Character movement and action triggers feel a bit lacking and sometimes the puzzles refuse to behave as intended until the game is restarted, making it feel like the game was designed by artists with beautiful vision rather than strict game buffs with a knack for nerdy menu designs and that is just fine in my book. So facing a beautiful and unique experience those were very minor glitches and that won't keep me away if sequels come and I sure hope they do.A breath of fresh air, I'd definitely recommend this one to anyone that can use a mouse.

												Lumino’s strongest assets are its fantastic art style, puzzle variety, and hint system. Those three make this adventure game a visual treat meant to exercise your brain. However, there a couple things that make it slightly annoying to very irritating throughout the entire experience.The story of the main game is extremely simple. You’re Lumi, a granddaughter, on a quest to find her grandfather, the Handyman, who’s been kidnapped. That’s all you have for the main plot for about five hours. You’ll learn about Lumino City and its current state if you observe the environment, read some of the books, and pay attention to the people. Once you beat the game and reach the credits, that’s when a well done wordless animation plays that fills in all the blanks. It’s a great way to ensure you watch the credits, but I don’t think having most of your plot delivered in the last couple minutes of the game is a sign of good storytelling.Obviously, the game’s use of hand-made materials resulted in many wonderful environments. Each area just pops out with its bright colors and excellent lighting. My eyes ate up the visuals and enjoyed looking at every area. It’s not a common art style that I’ve encountered which makes it that much more special. What can sometimes interrupt how gorgeous everything looks is the sometimes overly gratuitous use of the Depth of Field effect. Sure, it helps you focus on the scene in front of you, but sometimes it blurs out paths that you can take or even a few objects meant for player interaction. It shouldn’t have been allowed to be implemented in a way where it can hinder the actual gameplay. I really enjoyed how the in-game help system was developed for Lumino City. I thought it was clever and a little bit of fun. I do admit to just clicking through pages though after selecting the correct general area for some of them. The solutions are in chronological order within the 900-page book. The Handy Manual has answers whose page numbers are hidden by little math problems that require some figuring out since you don’t know some of the values. Usually, it requires counting something in the environment and then applying those values correctly into the equation and solving. Voila! Your answer or explanation will be at page number 50 or whatever the result is. I really liked not needing to pull up a third party walkthrough for 98% of the game and I felt pretty good about solving for solutions. Some puzzles are complex enough that one glance at the page will not do it, resulting in some back and forth. It’s easy to pull up during many of the puzzles where it has its own screen versus being in the environment. That’s due to needing a precise click on her bag which can be difficult in situations where the camera is pulled out.The puzzles don’t have a real theme tying them together like in Portal or Oxenfree. Instead, you’ll run into a good variety of them that have you solving in different ways. Some require understanding patterns, putting gears in the right place, placing lights to reveal a code, noticing the correct answer from exploration and then replicating it on a larger scale, and manipulating a light mill to display some messages in Morse code. There were a couple puzzles I just didn’t understand which required me to refer to The Handy Manual. There was also this wiring puzzle that required me to connect abstract shapes and numbers to one of equal value. I only understood half of it and applied brute force process of elimination to the rest. I thought most of the puzzles were good, some were delightful or amusing (the light mill and the very last one), and a few of them seemed nonsensical. Only one puzzle was tedious which was playing the guitar song. It wanted you to memorize six sets of notes that you had to play correctly at one time. It’s doable and I guess I could have taken a screenshot of the Handy Manual’s page, but that one felt poorly thought out.One of the major contributors to my annoyance with this game was the movement or lack thereof. There is no actual movement in this game. You have a scene with extremely static and predetermined points that you can click on to move. That means every time you click an area and have her start moving, you cannot stop or cancel it. You have to wait for the animation to finish in order to move again. As a result, the controls could feel unresponsive at times. I grew weary of having to see the same animations play repeatedly when moving around, especially between screens. You can’t skip to the next screen; the game insists on having everything play out. Thank goodness the game was only 5+ hours or I would have turned into an angry person.The other problem came in the form of stability and clarity. I’ll start with the latter. You remember how movement works between two points? Well, the Captain scene has a puzzle hidden underneath a hatch in the boat located between two of those points. I spent a good amount of time not knowing what to do and this marked the only time I needed to watch a video. Apparently it’s also a puzzle where you want to make sure you solve the boat’s rocking part last or you’ll have a large amount of trouble clicking the boat’s deck.The stability problem hit me hard in one area in particular. It was the moment when I when clicked on the guitar so that Lumi would start playing it. I ended up crashing the game twice and thought that was it. For whatever reason, it started working on the third try, but I honestly don’t know how it might turn out for other people. Be careful?Lumino City is a good looking game that provided puzzles that I could mostly solve on my own. Its Handy Manual made me work for the answers to the ones I couldn’t figure out which I liked. It provided a pretty neat experience overall, but it comes with a not-so-insignificant amount of issues. Some people might be more willing to put up with them more than others. Hopefully I pointed out enough things for you to make a decision.Favorite screens:

												TL;DR Play this game if you have any interest in artistic games. An absolutely brilliant game. The entire set is handcrafted out of paper and is beautiful to look at, the story is cute and engaging, and the puzzles are (for the most part) well laid out with a handy and well-designed book of hints for when you're really stumped. Absolutely worth the money, absolutely worth playing.PROS:* Beautiful design and artwork* Gorgeous music* Interesting and engaging story* Good puzzles with solutions that are on the right side of "not obvious" and "not frustrating"* In game hint system that's neither too tempting nor too difficult to access* Female protagonist without centering around her gender...* ...who deserves and receives the respect she earns through the gameFAILINGS:* Some puzzle frustrations: lack of clear goals, difficult to see/find targets, timing puzzles with awkward handles* A few hangs and crashes, two of which were reproduceable on my system (don't open the steam overlay when working with the water tank)* No audio/visual options, couldn't adjust sound-levels in game (music was too loud in the endgame for some reason)OTHER:* Puzzle difficulty leans towards "easy" but I'd rather easy than frustrating* Some of the stranger puzzles can be frustrating when you don't "see" what needs to be done right away, but every single one of them made sense by the completion of the puzzle. None need to be solved by pure trial and errorRead negative reviews closely, and you will notice a trend - complaints that boil down to disappointment that a point and click adventure/puzzler is too simple has no action elements! 												Pros: young female protagonist with brown skin, great puzzles, beautiful world and art, impactful storyCons: A couple glitches and crashesWho says you can’t receive something crafted by hand with paper and glue in a video game? State of Play expertly blends physical and digital art in their multimedia masterpiece, Lumino City. For this London indie games development team, their world-building process was literally to build a 10-foot-high model of the city out of cardboard, paper, glue, and some tiny motors and lights. The city we see in the game provides us a virtual tour through this model. It is absolutely stunning to witness the handcrafted elements bring every texture and scene to life.As a gamer who is beyond tired of the Damsel-in-Distress trope in video games, I found myself surprisingly refreshed by Lumino City’s take on the narrative. Lumi is a lovable, timid young brown girl on a journey to rescue her kidnapped grandpa. The story is simple but impactful—completely familiar but also impressively defiant. Through subtle but unmistakable details, Lumino City brings accountable storytelling to their whimsical of challenging but fair puzzles.LumeLume serves as a prequel, but it also feels like a proof of concept for Lumino City. The controls and navigation are much less intuitive than those in Lumino City (I was stuck for a long while just trying to figure out how to leave the house), and it’s a much smaller game. Though it may only contain a handful of puzzles, they are difficult and cryptic. Many of the puzzles are mirrored in Lumino City, but in a clearer and more accessible format. I would not say that playing Lume is prerequisite to enjoying Lumino City. It is only briefly referenced at the very opening of the game. If you are looking for challenging puzzles and simply more of Lumi, Lume is not a bad game by any measure. However, if you’re just looking for a single full, fun game to play, I would just recommend diving into Lumino City.The CityI still can’t get over how awesome this city is. Its construction is clever and creative, and it’s filled with characters who are not only memorable but diverse. For one, its mayor is a cat lady with pink hair, and the entire city is populated with many women, people of color, and people of all ages. Turning every corner only reveals more delight. Lumino City’s residents come with a variety of temperaments. Some of the puzzles can only be solved by first resolving disputes within the community, which become puzzles in themselves (like getting all the passive aggressive neighbors to help Lumi power the crane). Other puzzles require us to focus on healing interpersonal relationships (like an elderly couple whose anniversary isn’t going quite as planned). In almost every area, we encounter characters who are dealing with their own anger, self-doubt, delusions, and/or personal failings, and the ways they struggle to ask for help. As Lumi explores the city, she also finds subtle notes of disrepair and dysfunction. This isn’t how the city once was, and it isn’t how it should be. There’s much that is broken (and, of course, the Handyman is nowhere to be found). There are reminders of what the place once was: shining, well-oiled, and dynamic. Now much has fallen to the wayside of rust, tangled gears, and hopeless residents. Beyond the silly banter and the residual wacky spirits of the populace, Lumino City manages to place moments of small, solemn heartbreaks over this city that’s falling apart.PuzzlesThese puzzles weren’t a breeze, but they were definitely reasonable and well-designed. They were appropriately challenging and suitable for players of all skill levels. The point-and-click style of the game keeps things simple while demanding the careful attention of the player.Grandpa’s Handymanual allows players to adjust the difficulty of the puzzle (without altering the puzzle itself. This is an item that is given to Lumi at the beginning of the game. It offers hints for all of the puzzles in the game (though you have to solve a quick math problem first). You can solve all of the puzzles without using it, but it can definitely help make the game easier if you’re looking for something more casual. This built-in accessibility allows the players to decide for themselves how difficult the game will be. I love that these puzzles really are a part of the environment, and interacting with them lets you manipulate this beautiful, handcrafted world. It’s such a pleasing and rewarding experience through and through. (Though, the Spinner House was something of a headache.)Grandpa in DistressLike many puzzle games, Lumino City isn’t story centric. Most of my time was spent jumping from puzzle to puzzle. However, the light storyline is worth looking at. It follows all of the patterns of a Damsel in Distress narrative yet manages to avoid all of the trope’s toxic and misogynistic pitfalls. Grandpa is kidnapped, Lumi embarks on a journey to save him, Lumi helps him down from the high-up tower (or in this case, ladder), and Lumi is rewarded with a status increase (coronated as Handyman). This is the classic, familiar, damsel trope that gamers are all very familiar with. However, in Lumino City, the genders of the savior and the victim are switched, and the kidnapped victim’s character is humanized and relatively well-developed. The latter is accomplished largely through the subversion of the typical good vs. evil dynamic, where the focus falls on the hero and villain. Instead, Lumino City veils the antagonist until the end so that, for the rest of the game, the focus is primarily on the hero and the one she’s trying to save. These subtle but impactful changes throughout the story allow Lumino City to maintain a familiar narrative while creating a world that is fun for everyone; the story uplifts individuals while villainizing systems and institutions. ConclusionLUMINO CITY DOES SO MANY THINGS RIGHT.This game proves how beautiful mixed media can be, how clever and strong brown girls are, and how games with responsible storytelling can maintain appeal to a wide range of audiences. Although the game did run into a couple of glitches and crashes, Lumino City does so many things right, and its puzzles bring much joy, through and through. What an enjoyable and worthwhile experience.

												Lumino City is a great puzzle game.It provides a fairly expansive environment to explore, with a wealth of puzzles to solve, and the great thing is: They're actually puzzles. This isn't just some "run around until you can find the item that you need to progress, then combine them in just the right way" type of game. The tools you need are provided in each scene of the game, and you are left with a puzzle that you need to solve in order to progress.The puzzles themselves range from fairly easy, fitting cogs onto a board in the right way, to fairly tricky puzzles requiring  logic. All of them (bar one, in my case) were solvable without resorting to trial and error until the solution was found, which is a good thing in a puzzle game like this. There is also an in-game help book that can give you hints if you're stuck, without giving too much of the solution away.A big strength of this game is the art. The visuals were actually created in real life, then photographed into the game, which gives it a really unique look that I haven't seen much of elsewhere. This coupled with the great sound and music design make for a very nice play through experience. The writing of the story is also very good, with a lot of humorous elements combined with some more sincere ones, it adds a lot to the characters of the City.My one (and only) major gripe with the game is that there are parts of the game where you can solve a 'scene' in different orders. Say there are 3 puzzles. If you solve it in the order with the third last everything is fine. But there are cases where, if you solve the third puzzle first, the game either refuses to let you progress or it simply crashes on you. You then have to resort to the forums to see what exactly the 'correct' solution is.Aside from that, this is a very good game if you like actual puzzles without all of the running around aimlessly looking for the solution, and it just looks and feels great.

												Lumino City is a hard game to consider.  On the one hand, I mostly enjoyed playing it; I certainly don't regret buying it.  On the other hand, it's worth asking why that is.  The gameplay features puzzles that can at times make little sense, and at times be frustrating.  But even if you can't solve them by clicking on everything, you're actually given an item that contains all the solutions, so there's not a huge amount of challenge.The story is largely told in the end credits, and is not that compelling anyway.  During the game itself, you're mostly just moving from one region to another with little in mind beyond the fact that you have nowhere else to go.  Since you (almost) never return to a region, you don't get to see what effect your actions have on the game world either.The setting is somewhere between inventive and inconsistent.  It's not quite clear to me what sort of scale everything is supposed to be; are the characters supposed to be real humans, and if so, how did everything get built?  How do things work?  I guess you could say the end credits give you an answer, but I think there's still a lot missing there.Where this game really stands out is the set.  The fact that the world was physically built and photographed gives everything a unique and beautiful look.  The animations of the backgrounds are based on physical things moving, and gives it sense of weight and realism.  It does mean you're usually stuck with a fixed camera, but I never found that a problem here.So in the end, I've decided I can recommend this game ... but not at full price.  This is definitely something you can wait till it goes on sale to pick up.  At the least, you'll get a couple of hours of unusually pretty things to look at.

The game relies heavily on its visual appeal and indeed, the hand-made sets look delightfully colorful, and overall the game has a charming atmosphere.There is a coherent backstory, too, but it doesn't get in the way of the gameplay. Instead, little clues are spread throughout the world, and all the pieces are tied together during the ending credits. Be sure to stick around for that! The gameplay is fairly simple. You play as Lumi, who explores the City in search of her grandfather. In practice that means figuring out how to move from one screen to the next, which often requires talking to some people, finding a key to open a lock, and so on. However, this part of the game is fairly simple, and the main challenge of the game is solving its 34 puzzles.The puzzles are a mix of visual and logic puzzles, and are generally entertaining, though not all of them are very inspired. Some concepts get recycled a few times, while in other cases the puzzle is more easily solved by trial-and-error than by logical thinking. There is one puzzle which relies heavily on memorization, others require diligent application of look-up tables. If you get stuck, there is an in-game manual where you can look up their solutions. I didn't need it on my playthrough, but I peeked in after the fact, and was disappointed to see that the manual immediately spoils the complete solution instead of providing hints. That seems like a wasted opportunity.At $20, the price is a little high for a game that should take around 6 hours to finish, especially since it has little replay value. 												Lumino City is primarily a puzzle game with some point-and-click adventure elements. The game relies heavily on its visual appeal and indeed, the hand-made sets look delightfully colorful, and overall the game has a charming atmosphere.There is a coherent backstory, too, but it doesn't get in the way of the gameplay. Instead, little clues are spread throughout the world, and all the pieces are tied together during the ending credits. Be sure to stick around for that! The gameplay is fairly simple. You play as Lumi, who explores the City in search of her grandfather. In practice that means figuring out how to move from one screen to the next, which often requires talking to some people, finding a key to open a lock, and so on. However, this part of the game is fairly simple, and the main challenge of the game is solving its 34 puzzles.The puzzles are a mix of visual and logic puzzles, and are generally entertaining, though not all of them are very inspired. Some concepts get recycled a few times, while in other cases the puzzle is more easily solved by trial-and-error than by logical thinking. There is one puzzle which relies heavily on memorization, others require diligent application of look-up tables. If you get stuck, there is an in-game manual where you can look up their solutions. I didn't need it on my playthrough, but I peeked in after the fact, and was disappointed to see that the manual immediately spoils the complete solution instead of providing hints. That seems like a wasted opportunity.At $20, the price is a little high for a game that should take around 6 hours to finish, especially since it has little replay value. Those who are on a budget should wait for a sale. That being said, the game itself is well worth your time.

												The power is out, your granddad has gone missing, and you must save the city--one puzzle at a time! That's basically the story (and 90% of the character development is in the end credits, so stick around for that). But this is a fun puzzle game on par with Machinarium and other point-and-click puzzlers. There are the classic use-something-from-your inventory puzzles, as well as more traditional ones like "push buttons to get all the lights to go out" or "connect these differently sized gears" or "decipher this code" or "do math to unlock this thing." The puzzles are great, and there's a built-in hint system in the form of a manual you carry around with you, which is just a genius idea. The book is filled with diagrams (hundreds of pages, actually), and the hints are hidden within them. You have a list of hints at the front that take a little math to reveal the page number the related hint is on, or you can literally flip through every page to find them (they're generally in order, about one hint every 10-20 pages, and they're pretty easy to spot). Unfortunately, the hint book is incomplete, and I had to refer to the internet on a couple of puzzles simply because I was missing a tool that I couldn't see because of the art or I couldn't seem to access an area because of the UI. But all in all, great puzzles.Like Machinarium, it's main draw is also its main drawback: the art. The art is GREAT, a kind of craft meets photorealism. However, this makes it really difficult to distinguish what you can actually interact with in the game. The depth of field your character is currently in is sharp and crisp, with either the foreground or backround surrounding them with a kind of lens blur that adds a depth and photorealism to the world. Unfortunately, this means areas you can actually enter appear to be unimportant or inaccessible due to this blur. To add insult to injury, there is no way (to my knowledge) to highlight key hotspots. Your character can only walk to certain areas, and if you don't click those areas from certain other areas, your character won't move there, but since you can't find the hotspots sometimes except for random clicking, you just stand there clicking like an idiot until something happens. There was one puzzle where I was on a middle level, and in order for your character to understand the command to go to the bottom level, you had to go UP a level before the hotspot to the bottom level was even accessible. Your character wouldn't attempt to take the path of least resistance to a place you located unless you scouted the way for them. Every. Time. Frustrating. There are also a few, infrequent puzzles that require timing that were particularly finicky when it came to clicking on them because the hotspot was small and/or moving.The font of the dialogue bubbles is also really small, and obscured by a textured background. I was playing this on a widescreen monitor and I had to sit up close to the screen to read them. Also, you could click to advance (most) of the dialogue to get through faster, but it would automatically cycle through after a certain time. Don't look away from your screen without pausing first or you might miss a clue.So, overall, it's a good game (despite my main complaints, which 95% of them would have been solved with a hotspot highlighter function). But if you want a clever puzzler with great art and a clear aesthetic, you've found it. If you like puzzly point-and-clicks, you found it. It's got some rough edges, but it's worth a buy. I got mine in a Humble Bundle that I was buying for an entirely different game, so it was 100% worth it for what I got.7.5/10 for UI issues, but good puzzles.
